div.sent: The evergreen and ever fertile Bangladesh has attracted the attention of foreigners from ancient times.
Many ambitious men besides the general people came to this country from distant places.
Many of them settled here, again many of them founded states here.
But common people of the society seldom thought about changing power of the ruling class.
Actually, at that time the ruling class did not think about society.
The general people also led their lives according to the rules and regulations of the society.
As a result there was little scope for the general people to get involved in the affairs of the king.
Historian Koswambi said, In Indian subcontinent the villages were self-dependent and the village societies took care of the livelihood of the people.
Rabindranath said, A strong centrally governed empire was not present in the Indian subcontinent, here society was always a strong force.
But in spite of that, whenever society was oppressed by the state power, it strongly protested against it.
The na've poor rural people not only protested against it but also took measures to protect themselves.
They did not fear or hesitate even to rebel.
Some of the great rebellions and movements are referred to below.
The spirit of rebellion of the common people of this country is very old.
The first successful revolt by the common people took place in Bengal during the Pala period known as the Koibarta rebellion.
It was held during the reign of king Mahipala II (1070- 1077).
At that time, the fishermen were known as koibartas.
It was a rebellion of the fishermen community.
Four hundred years of Pala dynasty started at the beginning of 750 AD.
Dharmapala and Devpala were successful kings.
At the end of this golden age, some disorderly activities took place in the state during the reign of king Mahipala II.
There was also a lack of skill in conducting the administration.
That aggrieved and frustrated the people.
As they were skilled in navigation, they emphasized naval battle.
King Mahipala II was killed in the battle field.
After that, the Koibartas established their rule on Barind.
After Dibba, his brother Ruddok became king.
After Ruddok, his son, Vima, became king.
As a skilled ruler, Vima brought glory and prosperity to war-torn Barind to a great extent.
At last, Rampal ascended the throne and took all efforts to restore the glory of his fatherland, Barind.
After defeating Vima with the help of the kings of neighboring feudal states, he put down the rebel Koibarta state.
Thus, the first successful state revolution of the rebellious Bengalis came to an end.
Our economy is dependent on agriculture.
In the past, the farmers were suppressed by the rulers and Zaminders (land lords).
From the reign of emperor Jahangir of Mughal period, the intensity of suppression began to increase.
From that time to British period, innumerable peasant rebellions took place in this country.
The following verses of Dharmamangala poetry written by the eighteenth century poet Ghanaram express the intensity of the suppression on the farmers.
Obichare vange rajje Gaurer vuban /Pira peye patter palay projagan.
Rajkor lokera temni nilo bara /otoeb sara proja holo desh hara.
[The world of Gaura in the state broke down by injustice.
Aggrieved, the subjects ran to the councilors of the king.
The employees of the king were crueler.
They were tied with trees and were hit by clenched fists and Kora.
Kora was a twisted rope.
Its length was six feet and width was one foot and it looked like the long tail of an ox.
The workers of Zamindars would strike the farmers with this rope with all their strength.
They would hit them on their whole bodies, especially on thorax and bones.
One inch deep wounds were inflicted on various parts of their bodies and their skin was exploded.
Historian Suprakash Roy said, At that time many large and small peasant rebellions took place in Bengal.
Among those, the most significant rebellion was the Fakir-Sanyasi rebellion.
Among the leaders of this rebellion, Majnu Shah, Muda Shah, Cherag Ali, Vabani Pathak, Nur Alauddin, Pittambar etc. are commemorated in the history.
In this rebellion, besides the farmers and fishermen, blacksmiths, potters and the artisan class participated.
Besides the exploitation of local feudal lords and foreign merchants, another problem that the people were facing at that time was droughts.
These led to the famine in which about one crore people died.
The total population of the country was about 3 crore, which meant that one third of the total population died.
Yet, the English rulers and their accomplices of this country did not lessen the intensity of exploitation and suppression.
The suffering of the people became unbearable and so this rebellion spread widely across vast areas.
It also lasted for a long time.
The mentionable feature of this rebellion was the united participation of Hindus and Muslims.
There were Hindus and Muslims among the leaders.
Similarly, the people of both communities participated side by side in the rebellions.
This happened spontaneously due to the need of circumstances.
Many times, they protested and defeated the English soldiers.
Thus this, rebellion came to be known as the Fakir-Sanyasi rebellion.
Plundering the resources from Bengal, the English began to establish industries in their own country.
Thus, industrial revolution started in the western world.
It had far-reaching effects on production systems and world economy.
The inventions of steam engine, machine loom etc. also contributed significantly to the industrial revolution.
At the beginning, garments industry or machine loom spread.
At that time, most of the cloths were white.
To whiten those cloths or to keep them white, indigo, which was extracted from one kind of plants, was very effective.
These plants used to grow easily in our country.
With the increase of machine looms in England, the demand of indigo also expanded.
The English started to compel the Bengal farmers to cultivate indigo.
Cultivating indigo in the agricultural land was harmful for the farmers.
Besides, the price given by the English was not sufficient to meet the production cost.
Moreover, food crisis was sure to result due to less production of rice, wheat, etc. if indigo plants were cultivated in the soil.
So the farmers were not willing to cultivate indigo.
Consequently, to compel the Bengal farmers to cultivate indigo, the English adopted various means of oppression.
In the year 1815-16, in Bengal, 1,28,000 mound indigo was produced.
From then Bengal met all demand of indigo across the whole world.
But for that, the Bengali indigo farmers had to endure inexpressible oppression.
In this play, the heartrending and vivid picture of oppression on the indigo cultivators has been portrayed very clearly.
The pioneer of the Indigo rebellion was Sardar (Leader) Bishwanath.
But unfortunately he came to be known as Bishe dacoit due to lack of our nation's conscience.
Bishwanath was the hero of many successful struggles.
In 1808, he along with his 12 companions, was arrested by the English and later all of them were sentenced to death.
But that was not enough to stop the Indigo rebellion.
Following the religious reformative Oahabi Movement , in 1831 the rebellion under the leadership of Titumir again flared up in the Chabbish Pargona area.
The poor and the destitute responded to his call.
Under his leadership, a vast area consisting of Chabbish Pargana, Nodia and Faridpur was turned into a liberated area.
At one stage, the common people under Titumir's leadership challenged not only the English indigo planters and their accomplice Zamindars, but the British rule itself.
The Santal tribes live in north Bengal, west Bengal and in some areas of Bihar.
Once this area was called Santal pargona.
The Santals were very poor.
Actually, the zamindars brought these Santals from the west India for making them work in agricultural field.
Although they were brought up in nature's lap of Santal pargona, they had to work in the fields of local zamindars unpaid.
They got very little wage.
On 30 June of that year, a meeting was held and about 10 thousand Santals started to rebel.
The English soldiers and their police arrested the Zamindars.
As a rusult, the rebellious Santals had to face the English soldiers and the English govt.
The rebels fought with poisonous arrows and bows against the well-armed English soldiers and frequently defeated them.
Seeing their solidarity and success, the neighboring Bengalis both Hindus and Muslims stood by the Santals.
Sometimes the blacksmiths provided weapons; sometimes blacksmiths, potters and farmers fought in favor of the Santals.
But the Santals under the leadership of Sidhu, Kanu, Bhaireb and Chand made a strong resistance.
The English force faced a huge loss and finally they were scattered.
Being defeated frequently, the English at last formed a vast battalion and mercilessly attacked the villages of Santal rebellion.
The English soldiers first provoked and irritated 50 elephants and then they freed them to drive destructive activities in the villages.
Then the houses in villages were set on fire.
The English force shot innocent and helpless children and women indiscriminately.
Thus like cowards, they gradually succeeded in controlling the rebellion by killing helpless men and women and by setting the houses on fire indiscriminately.
The great leaders of this rebellion also became martyrs of freedom fights.
Such innumerable rebellions took place in Bengal.
This rebellion started from the Bengal.
